comments.commentBody: My understanding of Wittgenstein is that he was concerned with the games we play with language.  Much of what we say, philosophically and otherwise, is the consequence of the arrangement of words.  Through words (language) we generalize, creating laws or principles that we then take for actual entities, e.g., "Truth," or Beauty, or the Good, etc., but also political principles, classifications, etc.  But generalizations don't exist independently of the systems of language that encase them--only things do.  We resort to these language systems or games whenever we think about things we cannot see--for example, the many and various interpretations of historical events or eras.  It is still fashionable in some circles to conceive of the Middle Ages as dark, ignorant, a cultural regression, but some historians are revising that view and interpreting the Middle Ages as vibrant, inventive, and foundational to modernism.  But since no one can go back then and observe directly, the Middle Ages are a figment of language, not a thing or entity.  So Wittgenstein's critique applies well beyond the discipline of philosophy per se.

I agree that the White House and the Congress share the blame for the sequester, but my agreement with this piece stops short there.

The immediate problem facing America is economic growth and employment, an agenda item that is still pending. The U.S. economy is still stagnant and unemployment and underemployment stand at least 14% of the workforce. The safety net expenditures and reductions in federal tax revenues caused by the ongoing slump are a critical factor in the size of the deficit.

The logical course of action would be to focus on the economy and job growth first, and then turn to long-term deficit reduction. Instead, we've got both parties locked in a battle over the debt, while the sequester is poised to reduce employment by at least 700,000 jobs and quite possibly 1 million or more, as well as reduce the salaries of hundreds of thousands of federal employees.

Mr. Keller, many of his fellow pundits, and the nation's leaders are focusing on the wrong problem. The immediate threat is economic contraction and growing unemployment-- not deficit spending. It's time for the chattering class to wise up.

We are better able to exercise our "free will" if we study the way that language constrains us with its pseudo "truth". Roland Barthes says it much better than I ever can in "Mythologies". (But I'll try anyway). There is a thin line between "philosophy" and "propaganda." We pride ourselves on being able to distinguish between the two. We know where that line is. We can point it out----

Never realizing that we are up to our necks in propaganda, always have been and probably always will be, unless we are prepared to labor like Hercules to free ourselves.

Who is to say what actually occurred or what actually exists. It really depends on your viewpoint. I see something from the west; you see something from the east. Do we see the same thing? Yet what we both see actually exists. Or take history books: the victors write them. Does that prove what actually occurred?

Why so many words?  Truth is what actually occurred or what actually exists.  Because our brains cannot know the precise truth, we approximate, categorize, generalize, etc.  An objective truth exists.  But we must accept we cannot know it with any certainty.  The writer dismisses the widely held belief there is a "deep understanding to be obtained from the nature of consciousness."  To begin with, we know that we can learn.  That alone is profound.  We know we make decisions of moral or ethical import.  One may argue that is simply a cultural construct to support our species.  Or further, that such decisions are not of our free will, but rather, are "determined."  No matter.  Such decisions are still being made.  Ergo, consciousness is the portal to moral or ethical decisions.  Is that not profound?

First, California, Illinois, and New York have much higher human development than red states, and a large part of that is the improved health of their citizens. A large part of the economic woes in blue states recently have come from factors exogenous to healthcare costs, such as lower tax receipts due to a depressed real estate market, and the dependency of states with large urban areas on the viability of the housing economy. In any case, California has recently balanced its budget and is now running a surplus.

Second, it's not inconsistent to hold that Medicaid is a program for the poor, and for it to cover more than 20% of the population. The bottom quartile of households in America earn $25,000 for 2.14 people, which is rather poor. At $120 per person per month for insurance, health insurance would eat over 12 percent of such a household's income.

Third, it's a false dichotomy to suggest that health spending must come at the expense of education funding, or vice versa. We could, for instance, refuse to continue to maintain one of the the lowest tax rates in American history after World War II for the richest income earners in our society. While there's nothing wrong with rewarding success, we should not do so while "ignoring the needs of future generations," as you put it, by failing to adequately fund education. Anyway, health is complimentary to education. It's difficult and expensive to educate populations without access to basic health services.

Obviously the medical insurance industry needs help. It is a form of gambling based on an expanding population. It can not stay in business with a lot of sick people. Therefore, it either needs to be subsidized, or to somehow deficit-spend (which is my guess of how the boring, boring, boring NFL stays in business). I think the high price of medical care is from overhead, and not profiteering. A logical way to fund business subsidy would be to coin high-denomination coins and deposit them into the government’s bank account. This would cause no inflation compared with paying back the principal and interest on government and business loans. Those receiving subsidy could bill the government rather than wait for a grant, and that would solve the fear of too much power in the hands of elected brothers-in-law. Some doctors don't accept medicaid bacause it doesn't pay enough. That is why I treated myself when I got the gastroenteritis a couple of weeks ago. I fasted and sipped water (instead of getting an expensive IV). The doctor only accepted credit cards, and I don't qualify for a credit card because of low income.

Depends on what you mean by better. Better should mean better medical results. Private Medicare coverage HMOs offer Medicare coverage for just the standard Medicare monthly fee plus copays, which is better in terms of out of pocket cots - but you must use their doctors and their hospitals and their drug plans. With government run Medicare you have no limitation on doctors or hospitals whatsoever and you buy your own Part D coverage. The medical results are not available for comparison.

You talk about out of pocket costs only, as if those were the only basis for value and the care is equal - very doubtful!

From my experience with working with insurance and billing in a clinic, medicare and medicaid run by private companies are usually better than the ones run by the government because they give patients better values.
For example, with privately-run medicare, patients only have to take care of a small copay while, with government medicare, they are only covered up to 80%. The remaining amount of 20% can be a whole lot, especially for expensive procedures. For Medicaid, privately-run plans seem to have better doctor network. Of course, this is only my experience from working with about 4000 insurance plans every year.

This seems like a good point to note the twelve-million undocumented persons are not covered by Medicaid. When they enter an ER they must receive medical screening and medical intervention sufficient to alleviate life threatenning conditions. The hospital system is required by law to care for these people despite their inability to pay. Put private sector insurance companies into the Medicaid system and they will have every incentive to deny benefits to people because they were not properly documented. Count on people like Gov. Scott using privatized Medicaid to strangle a few more hospitals and to cheat doctors and healthcare professionalsout of their fees.

I assume you mean for patients treated for Medicaid, since it would be odd to require private insurers or employers to quit paying for the care of tobacco users. I disagree. The poor should not be subject to crass paternalism just because they have the misfortune to live in an era and in a society in which the provision of basic services such as healthcare is normally highly economically stratified, such that their only option for health services is the meager stopgap provisions of the welfare state.

That's in addition to the prudential concern that it seems like a really bad idea to turn away addicts from medical treatment. The parallel to heroin is telling: it would not likely alter an addict's behavior to deny them medical coverage, but it would very likely decrease their level of health, as well as increase the likelihood that they would end up uninsured in an emergency room costing more public money at some future time.

"For there is a lot of price-gouging in health care" -- this is the key point of this piece.

I am really hoping Dr. Krugman will follow up on that accurate remark in future.

Some thoughts...

What are the costs for standard medical services in other countries?

Why are they lower, by multiple orders of magnitude? Don't those hospitals have much the same "overhead?" (Answer: Yes they do.)

What can we learn from those countries about cost controls?

Japan, for instance, sets the national cost of an MRI at about $150 by law.

This is about two orders of magnitude lower than the $10K you might pay at an American hospital -- most of which outsource the actual reading of MRI/CT scans to contracted radiologists, to reduce risk.

Get the root costs of healthcare back to something sane, and maybe the healthcare industry will do as a good physician should -- heal itself.
The insurance companies and hospitals have had 40 years.  How do you think healthcare got so expensive?  We should go with Medicare for all now.

Let's give the insurance companies and hospitals ten years to bring healthcare costs in line with an international benchmark, say about one-third less per patient than we spend now, or else it's Medicare for All.

That should give the industry plenty of incentive to get serious about costs. Where is our National Commission on Healthcare Costs, as nearly every budget expert agrees healthcare costs are our main budgetary challenge? Exorbitant healthcare costs of course also discourage folks from hiring Americans, and Wall St. pressure makes sure they send as many of our jobs overseas as they can.

We can start phasing in penalties to the service providers for any amounts over this benchmark say after three years from today, payable as a tax. Measurement vs. the standard should start as soon as possible.

Brill's article explains how hospitals are using "chargemasters" (pricing master files) with dramatically inflated costs. Insurance companies routinely knock off two-thirds or more; it's the uninsured that get hit with the "chargemaster" prices.

We shouldn't have to rely on a brilliant journalist like Brill to wake us up to what is happening in the hospitals. Cleanup the chargemasters. Put the GAO on these guys. Let's get the Commission and incentives up and running.

The UK National Health Service is about to undergo a massive privatisation, and the British people are about to discover the problems with that system as in the US. The only motivation for this change is for private insurance companies and health care providers to get their hands on more public money. There is no evidence whatsoever that private care is more efficient or effective, and in fact the contrary is abundantly clear.
I would have to say that in UK there has always been a parallel, but separate private, system, and probably there should be such a system in Canada for those who wish it, but it must remain entirely separate.
Jim MD

The way the banks are allowed to meet their financial assistance commitment just seems counterproductive to actually helping distressed homeowners: if the bank just reduced the 1000 loans with an outstanding balance of $500,000 by say $1000, it would be able to take credit for $500 million while having actually forgiven only $1 million. This approach also gives the bank the incentive to focus on the larger loans: less work and more $$$ towards their committed assistance under the settlement. Either the article is missing some important details or the settlement is seriously flawed.

"Mexico: A Middle Class Society; Poor no more, Developed not yet" is a paper by Luis de la Calle and Luis Rubio accessible at:

http://www.wilsoncenter.org/sites/default/files/Mexico A Middle Class Society.pdf

The authors say: "...Even so, the middle classes of practically all modern societies, and all developed ones, share common characteristic: those who are part of the middle class earn enough income to live in an urban environment and want to systematically improve their social and economic standing."

They note about Mexico's progress, "...The fact that the Mexican Congress and Executive branch have devoted a larger budget for social spending also played a big role in allowing households to reassign their spending in order to soften the fall in income in terms of consumption per capita. In particular, spending on healthcare per household decreased 13.6% in 2010, which let families spend more in other areas, mostly thanks to the increase in public healthcare coverage."

http://www.wilsoncenter.org/sites/default/files/Mexico A Middle Class Society.pdf

While our attention is focused on Mexico's drug violence wealth there is increasingly "shared" and that is being accomplished in an important way by national health care.

Yet here, in the world's wealthiest nation, derisive of Latin America, the rich and powerful plot the exact opposite: lowering their taxes further and cutting social spending more.

They rush to make of us a "banana republic."
